title: Font common in print advertisements from the late 1970s/early 1980s (e.g., in National Geographic)
content:
This font may be a version of [Garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317124137/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garamond) or (more likely) [Cheltenham](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317124137/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham_%28typeface%29), but I haven't been able to locate a version of either of these fonts that matches the samples I've seen "exactly" (although the version used in the type specimen on the Cheltenham Wikipedia page seems quite close).

Here's a sample (from an ad for a lawn tractor):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317124137im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Example%20of%20font%20used%20in%20many%2080s%20print%20ads%202_6147.png)

Any suggestions (or, ahem, definitive answers) would be appreciated.

Font: 

 Century Old Style 

Solved By: 

 [fvilanakis](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317124137/http:/typophile.com/user/176276 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Example of 70s 80s ad font.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317124137/http:/typophile.com/files/Example%20of%2070s%2080s%20ad%20font.png) | 6.24 KB |
author: This is no way ...

comments.content: It looks like a **[Century Old Style](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317124137/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Bitstream&ffam=CenturyOldst%20BT%20-%20Roman&fid=afb5aed6171d84064caeba839543e8d2&fsize=60&text=Woods.%20The%2048-inch%20finish%20sitting%20down.&wrap=2)** to me.
That certainly looks like the font that was used; thank you for your help!
